newsitem.title: USA: Ascend stock falls on plan to buy Cascade.
newsitem.headline: Ascend stock falls on plan to buy Cascade.

text.p: Ascend Communications Inc. stock tumbled Monday following its announcement that it was aquiring Cascade Communications Corp. in an effort to broaden its share of the computer networking marketplace.
Ascend plunged by $10.50, or about 20 percent, to $41.50 in heavy trading on the Nasdaq market, where it and Cascade were the two most actively traded issues.

The descent on Ascend's stock knocked about $650 million from the original value of the stock transaction, which Ascend said was worth about $3.7 billion, based on its stock's closing price of $52 last Thursday.
Cascade lost $1.375 to $27 -- well below the $36.40 a share that its shareholders were to have received under Ascend's offer, which was announced late Sunday.
Under terms of the definitive agreement, Cascade stockholders were to receive 0.7 of a share of Ascend stock for each Cascade share they own.
Alameda, Calif.-based Ascend, which is chasing industry leader Cisco Systems Inc., is seeking to acquire Cascade to offer customers a full range of products for linking computer systems.

"Our products are highly complementary," Ascend Chief Executive Mory Ejabat told analysts during a conferennce call on Monday. "In addition to an excellent technology and product fit, Ascend and Cascade possess complemetary distribution channels," which could expand sales across accounts, he said.

The combined company, which will keep the Ascend name, also will be able to offer a number of products to companies that provide access to the Internet, the global computer network whose popularity is growing at dazzling speed.

Ascend said it would take an unspecified one-time charge in its third quarter for costs related to the merger, which will be accounted for as a pooling of interests to qualify as a tax-free reorganization.

"Assuming a third-quarter close to the transaction, we expect the transaction to have a slightly dilutive effect on Ascend's earnings for the remainder of 1997 and we expect that it will be accretive to our earnings in fiscal 1998," Ascend Chief Financial Officier Bob Dahl told analysts.

When pressed to be more specific, he indicated that 1997 earnings could be hurt by about 5 cents to 10 cents a share but the deal would add more than that to 1998 earnings. In 1996, Ascend earned $113.1 million, or 89 cents per share.
Ascend shareholders will own about 65 percent and Cascade shareholders about 35 percent of the combined company.
In a separate announcement, Cascade, based in Westford, Mass., said it expected its earnings and revenues for its first quarter, which ended March 29, to be below analysts' expectations.

Cascade said that, based on available information, it estimated first-quarter revenues would be around $90 million and earnings, excluding a one-time charge associated with its acquisition of Sahara Networks Inc., would be in the range of 14 cents to 15 cents per share.
In the first quarter of 1996, Cascade earned $11.3 million, or 24 cents a share.

Once the acquisition is completed, Ascend said, the company will reorganize into four business units -- multimedia access products, remote products, access and concentrator products and core switching systems.
Cascade Chief Executive Dan Smith, who will join Ascend as executive vice president of the core switching systems unit, said the company experienced uneven sales of telecommunications equipment.
"While the timing of customer commitments has been delayed, we have not lost any key customer accounts," he said.
Both Cascade and Ascend will announce first-quarter earnings on April 10.
